speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me a little bit about your birth, did you have any complications during delivery and did your mother have any pre-existing medical conditions?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I was born at term, and I was a bit larger than average, weighing 3000 grams. I don't really remember anything about the delivery, but my mom says it took a bit longer than expected to bring me out."

speaker: Doctor
text: Did your mother have any medical conditions that might have contributed to your larger size, such as gestational diabetes or hypertension during pregnancy?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, my mom doesn't seem to have any health issues, but she did mention that she hadn't been to the doctor much during pregnancy, so I'm not sure if that's a factor."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me a bit more about your mother's diet during pregnancy? Did she consume any high-calorie foods or supplements that might have contributed to your larger size?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I don't think my mom really paid much attention to what she was eating during pregnancy, but she did say that she was craving a lot of sweet treats and ice cream. She also mentioned that she was taking some vitamins, but I'm not sure what kind."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these sweet treats and ice cream - were they high in sugar or calories? And do you remember if your mother had any specific cravings or aversions during pregnancy? Also, did your mother have any concerns or worries about your growth or development during pregnancy?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah... I think the sweet treats and ice cream were pretty sweet, I mean, they had lots of sugar and calories. My mom would eat them all the time, and I think she even had some weird cravings like eating pickles and peanut butter sandwiches. She didn't seem too worried about me, though - she just kind of... hoped I'd be okay, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your mother's prenatal care, did she receive regular check-ups and screenings, and were there any concerns or issues raised by the healthcare provider during pregnancy? text: "Honestly, my mom didn't really go to the doctor much, like I said before. speaker: Patient

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these bluish spots, are they itchy or do they cause any discomfort? Also, can you point to one of these spots for me, so I can take a closer look?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah... they're not itchy, but sometimes my mom says they're a little bit tender to the touch. And, um, yeah, I can point one out for you... *points to a spot on my arm*. See? They're all over my body, but this one is right here."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for pointing out the spot. I'd like to take a closer look. Can you tell me more about the bluish spots, are they always the same shade of blue or do they change color? Can you tilt your head back for me, please?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, they're always the same shade of blue, it's just a deep blue color. And, um, I don't think they change color, but my mom says they're more noticeable when I'm feeling stressed or upset. I don't really know what that means, though." *Tilts head back for the examination* "Oh, yeah... I can feel you looking at my neck. It's kind of... bulgy, I guess. speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for sharing the results of the Genetic_Marker_Test. Based on the findings, it appears that there is a genetic component to your symptoms. The test revealed a mutation in the FGFR4 gene, which is associated with an increased risk of patent ductus arteriosus and other cardiovascular anomalies. This mutation is also linked to a condition called Williams syndrome, which is characterized by a distinctive set of physical and developmental features. Given the combination of symptoms you've presented, including the patent ductus arteriosus, congenital cataracts, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and the bluish spots on your skin, I believe that Williams syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. I would like to request a test to confirm the diagnosis. REQUEST TEST: DNA_Test. Please proceed with the test results."
